page.title: 10RIVER LOCK AT NABBS ISLAND
page.content: The area of the{River Trent}where the lock is situated is called{The Nabbs.} To cope with the 8 foot drop in the river, a top side bull-nosed weir has been constructed to relieve the pressure on the Hazelford bank. The 50 year old lock and cottage on{Nabbs {Island}are reached by a narrow metal foot bridge over the river. The lock is hand operated and is 85 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 30 feet deep. It holds a quarter of a million gallons of water and fills in 3 minutes. The 15 foot gates are made of solid oak with 2 sluices on each gate. A boat can pass through the lock in 12 - 15 minutes. The lock-keeper is on call 24 hours a day and has constant radio contact with all river traffic in the area.
